Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2025-03-18T16:20:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-02-25T09:24:42.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'On lines 80/81 and 83/84 you talk about these functions being disabled or overridden. Later you mention "restricted". You don't specify what "restricted" means or how these functions should be overridden. Should `safeTransferFrom` not check if the owner is a contract? Should they always revert?

The rationale given (not aligning with the MO-NFT's ownership structure) doesn't make sense. The safe variants to exactly the same thing as the non-safe variants, except they check for contract support. Essentially, if `transferFrom` aligns with the ownership model, then so must `safeTransferFrom`.

---

Disabling the approval functions is similarly ambiguous, and severely limits the compatibility of the standard. I, as an owner, should be able to approve a contract to act on my behalf.

---

I expect a lot more detail in the Rationale section about _why_ the above choices were made. They very heavily modify the ERC-721 behaviour and so require heavy justification.'}, {'prNumber': 844, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: AgentNFT Extension for ERC-721', 'reviewDate': '2025-03-20T17:23:54.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-01-12T01:01:38.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 841, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: Expirable NFTs and SBTs', 'reviewDate': '2025-03-20T16:46:29.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-01-09T08:45:19.000Z', 'closed_at': '2025-03-20T16:47:20.000Z', 'merged_at': '2025-03-20T16:47:20.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'Please fix these issues before moving into review. Such that if Tx A creates contract Z, then if Tx B calls Z it thus has to "wait" before Tx A has executed. The nice property of https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6780 is that we know that if a contract is creatd, it will now stay there, and can't be deleted anymore :smile: :+1:

- Your abstract could use a really short and simple definition of PBM right in the first line. Maybe something like: A PBM token is a wrapper around an ERC-1155 token that can be used for a limited activity. What you have is decent, but not succinct. Keep the technical stuff you have now.
- Your motivation section doesn't really explain why we need purpose bound money. Instead it explains why we need a standard. Your motivation could use one or two motivating use cases where PBMs are useful.
- Why define "PBM Wallet" as a term if it is exactly equivalent to just wallet?
- Line 49: `s/specify/specified/`
- Line 71: How is infinity encoded?
- You should separate the mandatory fields (eg. `name`, `faceValue`, etc.) into an interface that must be implemented. We generally don't want `contract` (abstract or not) in the specification section.
- Line 650: This is generally true for all smart contracts. On line 113, should "on" be "in"?

The purpose of the solidity snippet on line 115 is unclear. Perhaps some introductory text is in order?

---

This is okay to merge, but definitely consider these comments before moving into Last Call.'}, {'prNumber': 1064, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-4361: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-10T17:23:35.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-06-04T02:02:13.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "On line 41/42, the proposal mentions a couple RFCs. We permit links to RFCs; see EIP-1 for details.

On line 120/121, the proposal mentions ISO 8601. This document is not free to access, and so shouldn't be mentioned in an ERC. Instead, you can use RFC 3339 which is free to access.

---

This PR also needs approval from an initial author (@wyc, @obstropolos, @brantlymillegan, @Arachnid, or @awoie)."}, {'prNumber': 1060, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-7813: Move to Review', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-10T17:39:18.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-05-29T15:51:52.000Z', 'closed_at': '2025-06-10T17:40:09.000Z', 'merged_at': '2025-06-10T17:40:09.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'The "definition" approach to defining your standard is a bit... confusing. By the time I got to the `Schema` section, I didn't have enough context about how the proposal works to really grasp what's going on there.

You should probably write an overview early on in your specification section that sketches out how everything works so that when the reader gets to each definition they have a high level mental model that each piece can fit into.

The Fields Limits section mixes a lot of specification and rationale together. The specification section should include the limits themselves (eg. A record can have up to 5 dynamic fields), while the rationale section should have the explanation for the limit (eg. there is a max of 5 dynamic fields because...)

On line 242, "Store_SetRecord" should be in backticks (\`) since it's a code snippet.

---

Overall, this looks pretty decent. I think it's ready to move into review, though you should address this comments before moving into Last Call.'}, {'prNumber': 1029, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: uRWA - Universal Real World Asset Interface', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-10T16:52:56.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-05-01T07:18:56.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 991, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-7754: updating the acronym to avoid negative connotation', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-10T17:48:14.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-03-24T17:22:34.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 919, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-7750: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-10T17:29:37.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-02-25T09:29:08.000Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "Judging by the `registerCompany` function, this contract looks like it's intended to be shared between multiple employers/employees. Put another way, it looks like there would only ever be a single instance of this contract deployed on chain. Is that the case?

If so, you don't need an ERC. ERCs are useful when different parties need to coordinate without prior communication. ERC-20 and wallets are a great example: every token wants to work in every wallet and every wallet wants to support every token, but doing T*W integrations would be an impossible amount of work. Standardizing the interface makes all tokens interoperable.

Here, however, it looks like there's only one DES contract. Anyone who wants to integrate with it can just read your project's documentation."}, {'prNumber': 9708, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: Available Attestation', 'reviewDate': '2025-06-09T09:05:53.000Z', '2025-01-15T17:40:24.000Z', 'closed_at': '2025-01-21T08:31:17.000Z', 'merged_at': '2025-01-21T08:31:17.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'jochem-brouwer', 'reviewComment': 'I love this EIP! :smile: 

I think in general the idea here is that we only charge the cold gas cost once, and this is used to reflect when we pull this storage from disk. If that is the case, then I also propose we remove the logic from 2929  which reverts the journal of warm slots in case a sub-call reverts. This would make the implementation of 2929 for this fork likely much easier (since the revert mechanism does not have to be coded) and we thus now have that cold load costs for an account/slot are at most only charged once per blob.'}, {'prNumber': 9245, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-2537: Clarify the gast cost calculation formula for MSM', 'reviewDate': '2025-01-17T14:32:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2025-01-15T16:44:38.000Z', 'closed_at': '2025-01-23T14:51:24.000Z', 'merged_at': '2025-01-23T14:51:24.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'jochem-brouwer', 'reviewComment': 'LGTM! I now believe this is incorrect:

I indeed agree that it makes more sense to apply the execution refund before applying the `max` formula. Otherwise it is possible to somewhat "game" the gas system by getting refunds and then getting cheaper calldata txs. 

The simplest way to do this (assuming EIP 7702 is included) is to send an authorization tx together with the calldata, where the authorization fields delegate accounts which already exists. This (currently) yields 12500 refund, so packing these two together with the calldata tx will give 12500 "refund" on the calldata gas when it should definitely not be applied (the floor price of the calldata gas should be paid).'}, {'prNumber': 9193, 'prTitle': "Add EIP: Deactivate/Reactivate a Delegated EOA's Key", 'reviewDate': '2025-01-03T07:13:22.000Z', 'created_at': So it is correct :)'}, {'prNumber': 8948, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-7702: fixup gas costs and empty code hash', 'reviewDate': '2024-10-09T22:03:06.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-10-09T20:52:48.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-10-09T21:04:08.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-10-09T21:04:07.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'jochem-brouwer', 'reviewComment': 'Cannot hit "approve" since it is already merged, but yes this looks good to me :smile: :+1: '}, {'prNumber': 8945, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-2537: Remove redundant MUL precompiles', 'reviewDate': '2024-10-09T16:31:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-10-09T13:12:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-12-19T17:47:20.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-12-19T17:47:20.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'jochem-brouwer', 'reviewComment': 'One comment, some line got deleted which likely should not be deleted'}, {'prNumber': 8933, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: Add Controlled Gas Limit Increase Strategy', 'reviewDate': '2024-10-06T20:19:37.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-10-06T19:47:53.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-10-16T14:44:20.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-10-16T14:44:20.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'jochem-brouwer', 'reviewComment': 'Some comments.

In general I am not in favor of this approach. Because we currently have the freedom to let miners change the gas limit, this means that without a hardfork we can decide as community to scale up the gas limit. In case that a problem is found (for instance, a new DoS vector on blocks, like the Shanghai attacks https://ethos.dev/shanghai-attacks ) we can signal to miners that the gas limit should be scaled down (which can be done without a fork).

However, this EIP will remove this flexibility. If a problem is found and we need to decrease the gas limit as fast as possible, this means we have to fork, which will take a substantial amount of time.

As a general suggestion for this EIP: I would suggest linear increase of the gas limit, instead of an exponential increase. The exponential variant could lead to some rounding errors when rounding down to the nearest integer, which could lead to consensus bugs. The linear increase (constant gas limit bump per block) is also slightly easier to code.'}, {'prNumber': 8929, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-7702: updates for devnet4', 'reviewDate': 'created_at': '2024-02-04T19:34:36.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-08-27T21:00:48.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-08-27T21:00:48.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'This is looking pretty decent, but the biggest blocker is convincing me that this needs to be an ERC.

ERCs shine when multiple independent implementations need to interoperate without communicating beforehand. ERC-20 is a great example: every wallet wants to support every token, and every token wants to support every wallet, but there are simply too many combinations of token+wallet to build bespoke integrations for each pair.

This proposal seems like it would be a better fit for a library (with associated documentation), or for a smart contract wallet implementation.

To get this merged, please explain (in the document itself) who the parties are that need to coordinate on this topic, and why you need a particular implementation instead of just an interface.'}, It will be quite difficult to get sufficient technical review from the community if it stays grouped up like this. Are there any natural points where it could be split into smaller documents?

Size aside, at first glance it seems _very_ specific to a particular organizational hierarchy. I feel like I need to ask: who are the different parties you expect to need to interoperate? Proposals here really only shine when there are many independent groups that need to interoperate. Aside from members of the company, who do you expect to use all these functions? Is this document better suited to a Solidity library or template that orgs can choose to deploy?

Consider ERC-20. It's a great example of something that should be in an ERC. All tokens want to support all wallets, and all wallets want to support all tokens. Image if every wallet had to build bespoke code to handle each token; it'd be impossible. With this proposal, it seems like you'd have a single frontend for each org.?"}, {'prNumber': 196, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: NFT synthetic evidence', 'reviewDate': '2024-05-09T00:08:06.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-01-11T02:26:27.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-07-05T00:01:55.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 191, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: NFT Alternative Text in Metadata', 'reviewDate': '2024-05-06T17:14:59.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-01-08T01:34:09.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-07-15T00:01:54.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 185, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: Blob Transactions Metadata JSON Schema', 'reviewDate': '2024-05-06T03:28:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-01-05T05:31:38.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-05-13T12:43:39.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-05-13T12:43:39.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 176, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: ERC-7584 Linagee Name Registrar', 'reviewDate': '2024-05-08T13:19:58.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-12-27T20:30:51.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-07-05T00:01:53.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "Like @abcoathup mentioned, this proposal reads more like documentation for a specific project and not as a standard.

> Furthermore, the schemeId MUST be added to [this overview](../assets/eip-5564/scheme_ids.md)

Once this proposal goes to final, that file will no longer be editable, so this requirement doesn't make sense.

---

> This MUST be a singleton contract, with one instance per chain

You don't specify how the reader can find the singleton contract. One common approach is to use a universal deployer or "Nick's Method", but I am really not an expert on that kind of thing.

edit: ah, I see. I don't understand why this info is in the Backwards Compatibility section however.

> The recipient's address and the `viewTag` MUST be included in the announcement event

The "MUST" here creates a requirement, but this sentence is not in the Specification section. If you're explaining a rule that already exists in that section, use the lowercase "must". If you do intend to create a new requirement, please move this to the Specification section.'}, {'prNumber': 309, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-5521: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2024-04-02T14:16:05.000Z', 'created_at': '2024-03-11T23:26:27.000Z', 'closed_at': '2024-05-24T21:09:29.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-05-24T21:09:29.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "Looks great overall! My only complaint is that your rationale section doesn't really explain choices you made within the proposal itself. Instead, you're justifying the EIP as a whole.

The rationale section should explain why, for example, `UpdateNode` indexes some of its arguments and not all of them.

> Motivation: Why do we need to build a shed?

Taking a book out of MMS, have the actual message parameter be a URI so the message data can be stored off-chain. If on-chain storage is desired, a `data:` URL can be used. The message parameter type would be changed to `string`, and the schema would be turned into an actual JSON schema. Additionally, the following issues MUST be addressed: 1. The message schema must be added to the Specification. 1. The correct way to refer to an EIP outside of the EIPs repository is `[EIP-X](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-x)`. As such, changing a name shouldn't cause any issues, and so in this regard I am inclined to approve this.
2. The name is not part of a normative section, and although this does change the Specification section, it is a minor wording change. In this regard, I am again inclined to approve this.
3. I recognize many people don't follow the official recommendation in 1, and that the citation itself will change. In that regard, I am not inclined to approve this.

> A contract interface for managing deposits by defining a specialized address format.

----

## Additional thoughts

* Payment channels and zkRollups feel like a significantly better solution to this class of problems.  They allow both ETH and Token transfers to exchanges/merchants at notably lower gas costs than today, and they come with a number of other benefits over a solution like this.
* What advantage is there for standardizing on this?  Can't exchanges and merchants do the exact same thing that every dapp does when they want a user to call a contract (put a button on the page and the user interacts via their wallet)?"}, {'prNumber': 3293, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-1559.md', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-25T05:10:30.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-24T20:08:41.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-26T07:55:25.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-26T07:55:25.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3290, 'prTitle': 'EIP time based switch proposal', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-24T12:35:24.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-23T12:26:41.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-06-21T21:09:11.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "This feels very much like a Good Idea rather than a Standard.  The EIPs repository is for standardization, not a repository of good ideas.

I would really like to see a strong argument as to why this needs to be standardized.  Standards are good when you have a many-to-many relationship, like websites (many) to browsers (many).  They don't make sense when you have a one-to-many relationship like a Twitter (one) and integrators (many).

Standards also aren't necessary when there is little benefit to interoperability.  For example, if I build a dapp with some feature that dapp likely has a UI for it.  Someone else can build a dapp with a similar feature and their dapp will have a UI and there is no need for interoperability, so we don't need to share public surface area.  In fact, in situations like this standardization can lead to less innovation as people try to make their contracts look like each other without meaningful benefit."}, {'prNumber': 3283, 'prTitle': 'add whitespace after comma', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-24T10:35:46.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-22T12:57:19.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-24T18:39:13.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-24T18:39:13.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3279, 'prTitle': 'eip-draft-smartcontract-fee-share: Transaction fee share by smart contract deployers', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-24T10:40:33.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-20T19:35:40.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-05-03T12:02:52.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3276, 'prTitle': 'erc3156: Final Status', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-19T05:55:54.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-18T21:57:43.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-24T09:25:05.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-24T09:25:05.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'This appears to be missing an Abstract:

"I have 15 Ether" not "I have 15 Ethers".'}, {'prNumber': 3253, 'prTitle': 'Makes signature have type as the first byte.', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-10T12:46:12.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-06T14:16:54.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-06T14:43:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-06T14:43:12.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3252, 'prTitle': 'Make clear that Berlin is tracked in eth1-specs', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-06T04:10:01.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-05T17:26:54.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-03T21:06:41.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "My preference (mildly strong, will put up a fight, won't fight to the death) would be to just delete this whole file.

My second preference would be to move it to Withdrawn.

My third preference would be to keep the header data (so builds don't break) and replace the *entire* body with a single line saying that hard fork coordination occurs over at eth1.0-specs repository."}, {'prNumber': 3248, 'prTitle': 'Move EIP-3076 to Review status', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-04T04:40:14.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-04T00:29:38.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-09T06:16:25.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-09T06:16:25.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Overall looks good, but there are some editorial changes that I would like to see made before moving to Review status to bring this EIP in line with the latest standards we are trying to encourage/enforce.

----

"Serenity" and "ETH2" are transient names.  EIPs should be written with a future reader (5-10 years from now) in mind, who may not be familiar with ancient internal code names or weird versioning schemes.  Can we reword the simple summary to not mention either?  Maybe something like (I also shortened it a bit):
> A JSON interchange format for proof of stake validators for key migration between clients with slashing protection.

Title probably should be a bit shorter if possible:
> PoS Validator Data Interchange Format

----

> We propose a database interchange format that helps solve this problem. The format contains a record of all blocks and attestations signed by a set of validators.

EIPs don't propose, they assert.  Recommend just removing this first sentence of this paragraph entirely as it just seems to reiterate what the previous paragraph says, and shorter is better when possible.

----

> The above situation may sound far-fetched, but it’s actually very similar to the incident that occurred on the eth2 Medalla testnet on 2020-08-14, where a time skew that affected all Prysm clients spiraled into a series of cascading failures. It resulted in the testnet experiencing several days without finality – an outcome that could have resulted in tens of millions of dollars in collective penalties had it occurred on mainnet.

Consider just stating that this situation was seen in the wild due to time skew rathere than doing a mini-retrospective.  EIPs should try to remain as technical as possible and avoid including history, opinions, too much discussion, etc.  Motivation is meant to help provide a high level understanding of "why" this EIP is valuable, but it doesn't need to be exhaustive or even convincing.

----

> An earlier design encompassed two separate formats to achieve the same goal: complete and minimal (for the complete changelog see here).

EIPs are not the appropriate place to talk about history.  Write them as a moment in time, with all necessary information for implementation contained within the EIP.  History type stuff is best recorded in other sources.

If there is something specific that was tried and failed that you think is worth mentioning, explicitly call it out in the Rationale section as "X was considered as an alternative, but we decided not do do that because of Y".

Note: This feedback applies to most of the rationale section.  Try to clean up up the whole thing and have it self-standing rather than being a sort of changelog from vPrev.

----

Consider splitting up the Rationale section into `### <discussion item>` subsections to help make it a bit easier to read, with each subsection covering one specific decision (again, strive for each subsection being totally self contained when possible).

----

Test Cases should either be inlined, added as an `../assets/eip-3076/<file>`, or the whole section can be removed (it is optional).  External links tend to die over time and we do not have the manpower to maintain expiring links.

----

Implementation section should be removed (it is optional) or a pseudo-code implementation should be inlined, or an implementation should be included in `../assets/eip-3076/<files>`.  External links tend to break, and a list of implementations will almost certainly end up out of date and we do not have the manpower to maintain such lists.'}, {'prNumber': 3243, 'prTitle': 'ERC-3156: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2021-02-02T04:20:59.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-01T23:54:21.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-02-03T00:49:50.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-02-03T00:49:50.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Well formatted and mostly ready for merge, but it has a lot of references to external projects.  EIPs should be technical documents that stand on their own 5-10 years from now when no one remembers any of the projects that are around on Ethereum today.  Try to describe everything from the point of view of someone who isn't aware of previous/existing implementations of loans and instead prefer language that is agnostic to any specific project.

----

Remove external links and references to specific projects in the Motivation section.  In 5-10 years when someone is reading this EIP, most of those links won't work and individual products mentioned will probably be mostly irrelevant.  Recommend just rewording things so that you talk about the different strategies used by those dapps, but don't bring up the dapps themselves.

In Specification section, `lended` should be `loaned` I believe?  Or maybe `lent` (I don't think so)?  I don't think `lended` is a word in either case.

In Specification section, `lent` should be `loaned` I believe.  `loaned` is the past tense for `loan` and `lent` is the past tense for `lend`.

In Rationale section, remove references to specific projects.  Target audience of this EIP should be developers in 5-10 years who may not care at all about dapps that are around today.

In the Security Considerations section, same as above -- don't reference specific projects.  Stick to patterns, facts, assertions, etc. and avoid mentioning specific projects in examples whenever possible.  EIPs are technical documents and they don't need to include histories of things.  Try to describe the various security issue clearly without requiring the reader have any knowledge/understanding of existing projects. The idea is that any wallet that works with payment URLs would be able to send to whatever receiving contract that the recipient wanted.'}, {'prNumber': 2872, 'prTitle': 'DRAFT - Update Network Block Rewards to Adhere to "Minimum Viable Issuance To Secure the Network" Policy', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-12T06:22:36.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-11T17:27:55.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-03T23:06:35.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "My Opnion not as an EIP editor: I don't think that Ethereum should be in the business of trying to tune ETH block rewards based on the current market price of ETH or fee revenue.  1559 is likely to *significantly* change the miner revenue from transaction fees, and I'm reasonably confident it will make it into a future hardfork which further makes me hesitant to try to operate a monetary policy via manual adjustments."}, {'prNumber': 2871, 'prTitle': 'add a standard for claimble token', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-10T11:22:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-10T09:08:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-03T23:06:36.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'You have a file called `.DS_Store` that is part of this PR that needs to be deleted, and there are some structural problems that need to be addressed.

Separately, what is the reason for requiring building this into the token rather than as a separate thing?  By having it be separate, it could be used with every token in existence rather than only with tokens that integrate with this standard.  It may be worth discussing why this strategy is a good idea compared to traditional payment channel options in the Rationale section.'}, {'prNumber': 2867, 'prTitle': '2309 to Final', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-09T03:16:15.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-08T14:49:18.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-09T18:33:47.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-09T18:33:47.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2865, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-2803.md', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-07T15:42:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-07T14:48:59.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-08-10T11:08:56.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2860, 'prTitle': 'Switch validator to eipv', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-07T08:49:05.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-06T20:39:56.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-08-10T16:18:26.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-08-10T16:18:26.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2859, 'prTitle': 'EIP-1559: Changes specification to functional Python code', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-12T07:27:34.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-06T08:04:43.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-08-31T17:40:52.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-08-31T17:40:52.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2857, 'prTitle': 'Setting ERC-1271 to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-06T07:47:22.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-05T15:19:59.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-10T00:20:12.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': '* **Simple Summary**: One-liner "what is this".
* **Abstract**: What this EIP does (human readable).
* **Motivation**: Why this EIP exists.
* **Specification**: Technical (almost computer readable).
* **Rationale**: Why specific decisions were made.

Simple Summary is currently too long.  This should be one or two sentences that gives a 10,000 foot description of the EIP.  It shouldn't include reasoning *why* the EIP exists, or technical details about the EIP.  Just a simple statement or two indicating what it is.  Currently, the simple summary contains almost exclusively content that should be in the Motivation section.

The Abstract should be a human readable summary of the specification.  Try to leave the "why" of the specification out of this section and focus on the what.  Also, I generally recommend wording the abstract such that it stands alone.  When possible, try not to assume that the reader of the specification will be familiar with historic state of art, and just tell them about the specification in isolation (as much as possible).

The motivation section is where you should put all of the "why do we need this, why is it a good idea, who benefits, etc.".  Where possible, I recommend against linking out to external websites as we want EIPs to be able to stand on their own 10 years from now when other products may or may not exist.  Instead, try to give a very brief description of the class of product you are referring to like "exchanges where the orderbook is off chain" instead of "0x and EtherDelta".

In general, in the motivation section the thing I am most interested to see (especially for ERCs) is "why does this need to be a standard rather than just a 'best practice' or 'good idea'?"  I believe that is included in the motivation currently, but it may be worthwhile to pull that up to the top with an opening like:
> There are and will be many contracts that want to utilize signed messages for validation of rights-to-move assets.  In order for these contracts to be able to support non signing owners (i.e., contract owners), we need a standard mechanism by which the asset issuer can validate that a non-signing owner contract has authorized a particular transaction. 

The rationale section should describe why specific decisions were made in this specification, it doesn't need to just reiterate the motivation for why this specification should exist at all.  An example would be describing why you chose a particular name over others, or why you chose a particular parameter set instead of others, or why an event fires in a particular situation that may not be obvious (these are just examples, you don't need to include them if the reasoning is likely obvious to all readers or if it is arbitrary).

The EIP **MUST** include a `## Security Considerations` section, and for this ERC in particular it does feel like one is probably necessary since it is dealing with signatures (though I'm not sure off the top of my head what sort of security considerations need to be made here).

Where possible, consider inlining as much as you can rather than linking externally, or utilizing the assets folder of this repository to include larger content.  While sometimes linking externally makes sense, it also makes the EIP more likely to end up with dead links.  If there is an opportunity for a simple example implementation of this contract, consider including it inline in the `## Implementation` section.

All links to other EIPs should be of the form `[eip-1234](./eip-1234.md)` to ensure they work in all environments (GitHub, Jekyll, future website, etc.).'}, {'prNumber': 2853, 'prTitle': '1559 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Good enough to merge as a draft, but I wouldn't be willing to merge this to Last Call as it is (even ignoring the incomplete sections).  I recommend reviewing the feedback provided and making adjustments before submitting to last call.

Also consider adjusting the tense of the writing here.  I very much prefer to write EIPs as technical documents that target a reader base of future specification readers, rather than current/past readers.  This means instead of saying "there has been a size limit of ..." you might say "prior to this EIP there was a size limit of ..." (as a simple example).

EIPs are assertions, not proposals.  This means the EIP shouldn't say stuff like "we propose you do X", it should instead say "do X".  whether someone *follows* the EIP or not is a totally separate conversation that should not be part of the EIP itself, and once someone has decided to follow the EIP everything in it should be an assertion unless it is intentionally left ambiguous (e.g., **SHOULD** or **MAY**).'}, {'prNumber': 2666, 'prTitle': 'Precompiles and Keccak256 repricing', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-31T14:32:45.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-05-22T18:52:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-09T07:20:04.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-11-09T07:20:04.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'I recommend making the suggested changes (or something similar) prior to Last Call, but this looks well formatted enough to merge as a draft.'}, {'prNumber': 2583, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2583: Penalty for account trie misses', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-29T04:17:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-04-03T11:08:15.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-08-29T04:30:48.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-08-29T04:30:48.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2582, 'prTitle': 'Add `Table of Contents` to EIPs website', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-29T03:46:25.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-03-31T21:30:24.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-31T07:08:56.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-31T07:08:56.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Was also looking for this feature the other day.'}, {'prNumber': 2581, 'prTitle': 'Add anchor headings to EIPs website', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-29T03:40:25.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-03-31T21:27:14.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-28T16:06:00.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-28T16:06:00.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'I was *just* wanting this yesterday and wondering how hard it would be to add.  Glad to see someone already did the work!

I agree with @axic that we could probably "do better" with various levels of linking but I think even without dealing with that problem this is a pretty big improvement.  If someone wants to submit a PR after that tunes/tweaks this I would be fine with that.'}, {'prNumber': 2494, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2494 Baby Jubjub Elliptic Curve', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-29T04:35:34.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-29T08:39:57.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-09T11:08:08.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-09T11:08:08.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2488, 'prTitle': 'Add deprecate CALLCODE EIP', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-28T06:10:42.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-24T14:01:14.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-08-29T05:07:13.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-08-29T05:07:13.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Only change I would *really* want to see before merging is the addition of the `Simple Summary` to match the template.  While I know some editors consider the Simple Summary optional, I personally consider it required in the face of ambiguity (template doesn't explicitly say either) since I think consistency is valuable and in almost all cases it does add some value and allows for tools to include a one-line description as subtext in a list."}, {'prNumber': 2462, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2462 (Interface standard for Ethereum compatibles)', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-06T08:34:21.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-13T04:11:37.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-12T06:07:48.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Missing `## Specification` section.

Missing `## Security Considerations` section.

Missing `## Rationale` section.

At the moment, this doesn't look like something that needs to be standardized, and instead is just a dapp design or good idea.  Generally speaking, the types of things that need to be standardized are when you have a many-to-many relationship between clients and providers.  In this case, it sounds like there is a many-to-one relationship between users and Klaytn, and this specification is very specific to how Klaytn works.

If you believe there is actually a many-to-many relationship, you should define that clearly and make it clear what the expectations of the client are and expectations of the provider.  (e.g., what exactly is the provider expected to do?)"}, {'prNumber': 2386, 'prTitle': 'Ethereum 2 walletstore', 'reviewDate': '2020-08-22T13:31:13.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-11-21T22:37:41.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-11T05:12:51.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-11T05:12:50.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'The Security Considerations section is required before this can be merged as a draft, the other suggested change is just my personal suggestion but not a blocker for merging as draft.

---

Remove Implementation section (no longer a valid EIP section).

---

Is there *really* no security considerations?  Almost all changes to the protocol come with *some* risk.  For network protocols it is usually DOS risks. '2020-09-30T04:58:52.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-30T04:58:52.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'The EIPs repository is a place for standards, not "good ideas".  In this case, no standard is being specified so I recommend instead writing this up as an Ethereum Magicians thread, blog post, etc. instead of an EIP.'}, {'prNumber': 2997, 'prTitle': 'IMPERSONATECALL opcode EIP', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-30T05:55:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-24T03:48:30.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-08T04:25:27.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-08T04:25:27.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2996, 'prTitle': 'Update to All Status and the EIP process flow for EIP-1', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-24T02:42:09.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-23T17:22:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-05T10:07:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-11-05T10:07:12.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Left a bunch of feedback, but I think this change is an iterative improvement over what is there now and heartily approve it for immediate merge without waiting on any of my feedback to be addressed.'}, {'prNumber': 2995, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP-1654: Off-chain dapp-wallet authentication process', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-23T14:24:38.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-22T19:22:26.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-09T17:32:41.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Most of the content in this specification doesn't seem like stuff that needs to be a standard.  While it may be a Good Idea, not all Good Ideas need to be standardized.  If two dapps each utilize a different mechanism for signature validation that is OK.

Why is more than just EIP-1271 required here?  If a contract implements 1271 then it can validate arbitrary signatures and there is no need to have all apps verify the same signature.  Each one can verify something else and that is OK."}, {'prNumber': 2993, 'prTitle': 'Updating Comments in EIP 1271', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-23T14:02:13.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-22T05:52:15.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-11T09:09:28.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2982, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2982: Serenity Phase 0', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-16T14:48:14.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-16T02:51:22.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-08T13:37:21.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-08T13:37:21.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'The EIPs repository is for technical specifications, not end-user support/educational material.  If the goal of this document is to educate users about the high level view of an upcoming change in Ethereum, then a blog post or website article would be a more appropriate medium, or even just a Readme on the linked repository.

Recommendation:
Either convert/move this document elsewhere, or move the entire ETH2 spec into the EIPs repository.  Trying to have only a small portion of the spec in the EIPs repository (which is likely to end up out of sync with reality if not maintained as the canonical source of information) is likely to lead to a maintenance nightmare, not to mention this repository isn't the place for that kind of content.

I left some other minor feedback, but upon realizing that this isn't actually a technical specification I mostly stopped reviewing as I think that most other feedback I give is just going to be me saying over and over "this shouldn't be part of a technical specification".'}, {'prNumber': 2981, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2981: ERC-721 Royalty standard - Standardized means of accepting royalties for NFT marketplaces across the ecosystem', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-16T03:07:13.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-15T06:05:20.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-22T10:13:29.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-22T10:13:29.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2980, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2980: Swiss Compliant Asset Token', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-16T14:24:14.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-14T16:05:39.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-19T11:01:20.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-19T11:01:20.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'A standard is valuable when there is a many-to-many relationship between parties.  An example of something that needs a standard is web pages because there are many browsers that come and go over time and there are many web pages on the internet that come and go over time.  In order for all web pages to work on all browsers, we need a standard.  If you have a one to many relationship or a one to one relationship, then you don't need a standard and instead just have a Good Idea that you can implement.

In this case, the issuer-only functions are a "good idea" and not part of the standard in terms of interface design.  They may be required by a governing body (like Swiss government), but that just means that *implementations* need to implement those functions with certain behaviors, but that is unrelated to an interoperability standard like this one.  A number of the comments in this review are just deleting those functions.'}, {'prNumber': 2976, 'prTitle': '2976: eth/##: Typed Transactions over Gossip', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-13T17:23:51.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-13T11:29:56.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-13T12:08:42.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-13T12:08:42.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2975, 'prTitle': 'Add IS_STATIC opcode', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-13T06:20:59.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-13T01:36:48.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-13T06:21:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-13T06:21:12.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2969, 'prTitle': 'EIP-1: require at least one github username', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-11T14:43:12.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-11T14:03:25.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-06T07:10:03.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-11-06T07:10:03.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'My feedback is all around EIP-1 conventions, nothing wrong with this particular PR.'}, {'prNumber': 2964, 'prTitle': 'add EIP-2266 example', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-11T01:24:52.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-10T10:52:43.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-11T01:36:22.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-11T01:36:22.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2955, 'prTitle': 'eip-2565: rework it', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-08T12:45:41.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-09-08T11:59:37.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-23T09:15:53.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Merging is up to the authors, but I left some general comments. However, this EIP is well formatted enough as-is to merge as a draft."}, {'prNumber': 2926, 'prTitle': 'Chunk-Based Code Merkleization', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-01T17:14:00.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-31T17:33:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-01T17:14:42.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-01T17:14:42.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': '🚢'}, {'prNumber': 2924, 'prTitle': 'Changes 1559 to have a single shared pool for all transactions.', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-30T11:42:56.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-29T06:10:22.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-06T14:04:34.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-06T14:04:34.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2892, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-2565 to clarify specification', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-24T11:07:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-08-21T16:27:22.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-08T04:31:51.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-08T04:31:51.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'My feedback still remains largely the same as my previous review.  The vast majority of the text you have in this EIP currently should be moved to the Motivation and Rationale section.  As a *specification* this EIP is incredibly simple.  "Set gas cost of precompile X to Y".  Motivation is a great place to go into details as to why you think this change is a good idea broadly speaking, and Rationale section is a great place to discuss the various options you considered and your methodology for coming up with `Y`.

The Simple Summary, Abstract, and Specification sections though should really focus *solely* on the specification itself and not discuss any of the other things.

Also, keep in mind that EIPs don't make suggestions, they make assertions.  People can choose to follow the EIP or not if they want, but the EIP should be written to target people who *are* following it and trying to implement.

Something to keep in mind is that the mechanism by which you calculated the new gas cost is not part of the specification.  It is very reasonable to include that in the rationale section, but it isn't appropriate for the summary/abstract/specification section.

Also keep in mind that EIPs that change gas prices generally don't have hard dependencies on historic gas prices.  While the gas cost of precompile X may be Y right now on Ethereum mainnet, over on Ethereum Classic or some testnet it may have been Z.  This specification doesn't care about the historic gas price of the precompile, so it shouldn't mention it in the specification.  It *may* be relevant in the motivation or rationale section, but generally speaking we want EIPs to specify single moments in time without care for what came before or what may come after.'}, I left some feedback that I encourage checking out but nothing that blocks merging as a draft.'}, {'prNumber': 2494, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2494 Baby Jubjub Elliptic Curve', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T06:21:52.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-29T08:39:57.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-09T11:08:08.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-09T11:08:08.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2474, 'prTitle': 'EIP: Coinbase Calls', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T08:11:57.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-19T06:05:18.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-03T01:48:43.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-03T01:48:43.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Minor formatting adjustments, but otherwise looks good to merge.  @3esmit is this still desired given that EIP-1559 is likely to make it so miners have to pay some amount for gas?'}, {'prNumber': 2467, 'prTitle': 'Set ERC-1620 to "Last Call"', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T12:29:09.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-14T18:10:14.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-15T15:06:34.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'It is unclear to me why this needs to be a standard rather than just a "good idea".  An interface standard is useful when you have a many-to-many relationship like browsers (many) to websites (many) and when you don't have a fixed set of either one up front (new browsers come and go, new websites come and go).  In this case, each stream arrangement will involve exactly 2 parties, and those parties can agree on using whatever interface/tools they want.  It is unclear why we need a global standard that all money streams need to follow.  Can instead people just use some application like Sablier?

The specification also feels unnecessarily large in the case where we want standardized tooling (e.g., wallets) to support current stream balances.  It seems like a simple:
```solidity
interface MoneyStream {
    function balanceOf(address user) returns (uint256 amount);
}
```
would be sufficient so users can see their current balance of a given money stream.  Perhaps one more function for getting the details of the stream.

A potentially better pattern here may be to create a new contract per stream, rather than having a single contract that encapsulates multiple streams.  Perhaps in the rationale section you could describe why multiple streams per contract is valuable or necessary?'}, {'prNumber': 2456, 'prTitle': 'Time Based Upgrade Transitions', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-27T06:19:51.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-01-07T23:30:34.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-28T04:29:54.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'This looks good for getting merged as a draft aside from the extraneous comments (new policy is to remove them).'}, {'prNumber': 2430, 'prTitle': 'EIP-1191: Set status Final and remove adoption table', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-12T06:18:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-12-07T16:53:41.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-18T07:07:40.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'The backward compatibility section says:
> This proposal is fully backward compatible. The checksum calculation is changed only for new networks that choose to adopt this EIP and add their chain numbers to the Adoption Table included in this document.

But I don't believe this is true at all.  If you have an EIP-55 checksumed address, it will fail validation EIP-1191 validation, and if you have a EIP-1191 checksummed address it will fail EIP-55 validation.  Also, you mention the adoption table which has since been removed, so the reference here should be removed as well.

I recommend describing in the backward compatibility section that checksums generated/validated by this EIP will *not* be interoperable with tools that generate/validate EIP-55 checksums and perhaps recommend strategies for tools to deal with this situation.

I believe this was mentioned elsewhere previously, but keep in mind that this is not a consensus change so there is no way to ensure that an entire ecosystem follows this EIP, so in many cases people will need to deal with this incompatibility.

---

> If the chain id passed to the function belongs to a network that opted for using this checksum variant

Since this is not a consensus change, a network cannot opt to use this variant.  A given tool can choose to use this variant, or a user can choose to use this variant, but a network as a whole cannot make such a decision because there is not a mechanism for achieving consensus on the issue.  Note: Just because all of the tools for a given network happen to follow this doesn't mean that the network has opted to use this variant, it just means that all of the individual tools that happen to be written for that ecosystem today have chosen to use this variant, and that could change at any moment as soon as someone introduces a new tool.

Given that, this part of the specification needs to be reworded to correctly indicate *who* is making the choice to use this change.  Also, a specification really should avoid conditionals where possible, so I would reword it to something like:
> When calculating the checksum for an address, prefix the address with the chain ID and the 0x separator before calculating the hash.

---

> prefix the address with the chain id and the 0x separator before calculating the hash.

This isn't specific enough.  Is the chain ID and `['0', 'x']` prepended to the address bytes as a number (if so, how is it encoded), or is it prepended as a base 10 string number followed by the string `0x` followed by the hexadecimal encoded address (all lowercase or all uppercase?).

---

The current rationale section contains content more appropriate for the `## Motivation` section.  The Motivation section is where you provide context on why this EIP is a good idea, while the Rationale section describes why you made some of the choices that you made.  An example of something the rationale section should probably contain is "why is the `0x` prefix included in the middle of the value" and "why is the hex encoded address hashed instead of hashing a number or a byte array?"

---

> network.For example, if this EIP is implemented, a wallet can alert the user that is trying to send funds to an Ethereum Testnet address from an Ethereum Mainnet wallet.

Need a space between sentences here, and also the EIP should be worded as an assertion, not a conditional. Consider the following (with a couple minor grammatical fixes included):
> A wallet that implements this EIP can alert the user that they are trying to send funds to an Ethereum Testnet address from an Ethereum Mainnet wallet.'}, {'prNumber': 2427, 'prTitle': 'historic-blockhashes', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T08:27:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-12-04T18:52:53.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-10T16:07:24.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Along with the suggested changes, this EIP also needs all of the sections found in the template: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ethereum/EIPs/master/eip-template.md

Is there still interest in this over https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2935 ?  If not, it may be worthwhile to consolidate effort into one of the two.'}, {'prNumber': 2390, 'prTitle': 'GeoENS pull request - initial revision', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T09:31:38.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-11-25T14:48:52.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-13T06:09:52.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-13T06:09:52.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2386, 'prTitle': 'Ethereum 2 walletstore', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-11T05:12:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-11-21T22:37:41.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-09-11T05:12:51.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-09-11T05:12:50.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Merging as draft, recommend considering the other comments I and others have left.'}, {'prNumber': 2381, 'prTitle': 'Add ENS support for addressing ERC721 NFTs', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T10:09:04.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-11-15T11:37:56.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-16T04:53:14.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2375, 'prTitle': 'ENS support for canonical names', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T10:11:41.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-11-12T18:02:27.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-07T01:31:57.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2219, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP 918 to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-10T05:46:55.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-07-30T02:41:00.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-17T03:06:59.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "The motivation section should explain why this needs to be a Standard rather than just a Good Idea since it isn't immediately obvious.  A standard is valuable when there is a many-to-many relationship between parties.  An example of something that needs a standard is web pages because there are many browsers that come and go over time and there are many web pages on the internet that come and go over time.  In order for all web pages to work on all browsers, we need a standard.  If you have a one to many relationship or a one to one relationship, then you don't need a standard and instead just have a Good Idea that you can implement.

In this case there is a one to one relationship between the token and the mining interface, so it doesn't seem like there is a need for a standard.  Each token will have its own user interface (because they each will have their own PoW function) and they can each define whatever contract interface they like.

----

Interface standards should never define internal behavior, as that is an implementation detail.  This standard defines several internal functions which should all be removed.

The same for the implementation details of the functions.  While a reference implementation can be useful in the `## Implementation` section, it is not part of the specification and instead you should only define publicly visible behavior expectations, not internal implementation details of how to achieve that behavior."}, {'prNumber': 2185, 'prTitle': 'Skinniest CREATELINK', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-09T16:06:29.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-07-10T06:46:52.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-11-29T06:09:13.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "I believe it will be necessary to discuss how this interacts with `SELFDESTRUCT` on the linked contract, but that isn't necessary for Draft status."}, {'prNumber': 1691, 'prTitle': '#1690 added Mortability Standard', 'reviewDate': '2020-09-22T10:22:17.000Z', 'created_at': '2019-01-11T12:30:45.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-04T05:08:58.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Sorry for the delay in getting to this @Felix-Franz.  We have historically not been great at getting back to people and getting drafts merged, but we are working on getting through all of the backlog and getting to a place where EIPs get merged reliably.

'2024-07-09T14:19:17.000Z', 'merged_at': '2024-07-09T14:19:17.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'Please only use backticks (`\``) for inline code. You're using them in your motivation section for definitions.

---

Those definitions in your motivation section, why are they there? Are they used later in the document, and need specific definitions? If so, please move them to the Specification section. If they're supposed to be motivating examples, maybe try changing the formatting to make that more clear?

---

Where is "set mint" (line 52) defined?

---

On line 54, try to describe the externally visible behaviour of the contract. Like instead of "if the token burns, the properties MUST be deleted", how about "if the token is burned, `getProperties` MUST revert"

---

On line 127, you aren't really stating a requirement on implementers. You should describe the behaviour of the contract _if `setProperties` is not called_, instead of saying how the contract is supposed to be used.

---

On line 139, you mention an `_update` function that must be overridden. `_update` doesn't exist in the ERC-721 standard. I believe it's part of OpenZeppelin's implementation. Instead of referencing a specific implementation here (at the risk of sounding like a broken record) you should describe the externally visible behaviour of the contract in terms of the functions in ## Security Considerations
All EIPs must contain a section that discusses the security implications/considerations relevant to the proposed change. Include information that might be important for security discussions, surfaces risks and can be used throughout the life cycle of the proposal. E.g. include security-relevant design decisions, concerns, important discussions, implementation-specific guidance and pitfalls, an outline of threats and risks and how they are being addressed. EIP submissions missing the "Security Considerations" section will be rejected. An EIP cannot proceed to status "Final" without a Security Considerations discussion deemed sufficient by the reviewers.

* remove the [1] from underneath the copyright section'}, {'prNumber': 4649, 'prTitle': 'New EIP request', 'reviewDate': '2022-01-10T22:15:23.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-01-09T01:46:30.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-11T02:13:47.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'lightclient', 'reviewComment': '@jeyakatsa it feels like this idea should live in the Ethereum Magicians forum until it's more fleshed out. The specification doesn't detail how one would write smart contracts in other languages.

Regarding the EIP itself, it feels like you're conflating some different ideas, so maybe let me clarify a couple things:
- An ERC is an application standard for Ethereum smart contracts. There is of course the ERC tokens, ERC-20 and ERC-721. But there also non-token ERCs, such as ERC-165 which describes how a contract can signal what functions it implements. Therefore, your title "ERC Token in Multiple Languages" confuses me because it isn't clear what ERC you're referring to.
- Token standards on Ethereum define an _interface_ for interacting with a deployed contract and the behavior of each method. That interface typically follows the [contract ABI](https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/v0.8.11/abi-spec.html) standard. It seems a bit futile to re-implement well defined token standards in another language when there are good implementations in solidity and viper that can be used off the shelf.
- Maybe what you're more getting to is that it could be valuable to allow java, go, rust, etc. devs to directly write smart contracts in their preferred language. This makes more sense to me than re-implementing token contracts. In that case, I don't think that makes sense as an ERC. Solidity isn't an ERC, neither is Viper. The EVM is already well defined so you are able to design whatever compilation pipeline you like, as long as it targets EVM bytecode. IIRC, there was actually an effort from ETC Core to maintain a version of LLVM that could compile EVM. This would allow many languages to compile direction to EVM.
- As someone who has spent a fair bit of time looking at and considering how general programming languages could be used in a blockchain env (mainly via wasm), I found that usually didn't make a lot of sense. Compilation pipelines are very complex and typically designed for compiling to physically hardware. There are also lots of EVM-specific operations that don't have first class respect in typical languages. Adding support for these things often ended creating a [frankenstein](https://github.com/quilt/sheth/blob/master/src/lib.rs#L46) combination of macros, libraries, etc. '}, {'prNumber': 4645, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-4626.md', 'reviewDate': '2022-01-09T16:24:34.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-01-08T18:07:04.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-12T08:44:50.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-01-12T08:44:49.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'lightclient', 'reviewComment': 'Sorry I missed a few occurrences of `ERC20`. In this case, you should also shorten it down to about a sentence, consider something like this:
```
description: A standard way for contracts to verify if a provided signature is valid when the account is a smart contract.
```

----
EIP links should be relative, change 
```
[EIP-712](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-712)
```
to
```
[EIP-712](./eip-712.md)
```'}, {'prNumber': 4716, 'prTitle': '4200: Change to Review', 'reviewDate': '2022-01-25T10:02:49.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-01-24T13:01:54.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-25T11:01:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-01-25T11:01:11.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4692, 'prTitle': 'Move EIP-2315 to Review', 'reviewDate': '2022-01-19T04:54:57.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-01-18T01:59:19.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-30T02:38:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-01-30T02:38:12.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "This currently depends on 3540 (Review), 3670 (Review), 3779 (Draft), and 4200 (Draft).  Any dependencies need to be at least as far along in the EIP process as the dependent, which means this can't move to Review until 3779 and 4200 are in Review.  I didn't dig deep into the technical details for those dependencies, but if they aren't strictly required then an appropriate course of action may be to just remove the dependency.  If you decide to go that route, you'll need to remove the external link to EIP-3779 and EIP-4200 in the Specification and Backward Compatibility sections.

----

External links should be removed before merging into Review.  Specifically this line:
> The [concept](https://people.cs.clemson.edu/~mark/subroutines.html) goes back to [Turing's Automatic Computing Engine of 1946](http://www.alanturing.net/turing_archive/archive/p/p01/P01-001.html):

I recommend just keeping the text and the attached quote, without the links.  If someone wants to look up the source of the quote they can just do an internet search for it, though that shouldn't matter because the argument should stand on its own without needing to appeal to an authority (especially one from 80 years ago).

----

I personally recommend removing the entire History section.  I generally let people include just about whatever they want in the Motivation (aside from external links), so this isn't a blocker but I think history lessons are way out of scope for an EIP.  The motivation section should be brief in explaining the value this standard adds to the ecosystem and leave it up to the user or the discussions-to for additional argumentation/context.

----

Test Cases section should be above the Security Considerations section.

----

Editor note: I just wanted to say how I appreciate your Test Cases section.  Most EIPs don't include any test cases, or if they do they are ill defined.  The test cases here are quite above the bar and I'm very happy to see them!"}, {'prNumber': 4677, 'prTitle': 'Typo in eip-191', 'reviewDate': '2022-01-15T08:33:00.000Z', 'created_at': Should be a short description (about a sentence) of this EIP meant for humans to be reminded of the EIP's contents.

Remove Implementation section.  There is an optional Reference Implementation section, but since you don't appear to have one or it isn't applicable here it should be left out.

Add missing Security Consideration section just before the Copyright section.

Remove external link to Wikipedia for `phone`.

----

I'm going to keep saying this on each of these ENS EIPs, even though it isn't a blocker I do feel pretty strongly that these should not be in the EIPs repository.  ENS is an application that should have its own documentation.  It doesn't need standardization because there is one ENS and many ENS consumers.  This is a prime example of where documentation is required, not standardization."}, {'prNumber': 4428, 'prTitle': 'Unstagnant EIP-3224', 'reviewDate': '2021-11-07T04:27:20.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-11-07T04:15:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-11T05:26:34.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-11-11T05:26:34.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "The Simple Summary section should be removed and a `description` header field should be added below `title` that contains essentially the same thing.  Try to keep it as short as possible, one sentence (and one line, don't hardcode newlines).

Remove external links from Test Cases.  Contracts that the tests are run against should be included either as an asset or inline, or just left out if they aren't required."}, {'prNumber': 4424, 'prTitle': 'Move EIPs 2363 & 2464 to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2021-11-08T02:20:49.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-11-05T21:20:05.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-11T23:05:25.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-11-11T23:05:24.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ">The specification is tiny since most parts are already specified in EIP-2124. `eth/63` is not specified as an EIP, but is maintained [here](https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/eth.md).

> I don’t believe this proposal is effective:
>
>  1.  Tokens can pretend to be refundable, but not actually allow refunds.
>  1.  If refunds only belong to the first buyer, then it encourages reselling, and provides little  benefit to “actual users”.
> 1.    An escrow contract could accomplish the same thing, for any transaction, not just for the first buyers. This would work for older NFTs too!
"}, {'prNumber': 7015, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: NFT Creator Attribution', 'reviewDate': '2023-05-30T15:49:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-05-11T18:26:45.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-06-02T00:38:32.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-06-02T00:38:32.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 6997, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: ERC-721 with transaction validation step.', 'reviewDate': '2023-05-08T17:24:04.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-05-07T14:55:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-06-02T00:40:26.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-06-02T00:40:26.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 6992, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: ECC DSS signatures', 'reviewDate': '2023-05-30T15:37:45.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-05-05T20:06:32.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-05-30T17:49:45.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 6991, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-6953: Move to Review', 'reviewDate': '2023-05-08T19:40:18.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-05-05T14:38:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-05-25T22:04:15.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'I'd be careful about this EIP. If it goes to final, you won't be able to update it any further, so it won't be an "exhaustive" list.

If you'd like living status, you'd want to bring it up at an EIPIP meeting.

 - `EIP6065Immutable` comment (Lines 57 - 70) should be removed. While we do allow some suggestions for implementers in complex cases, I don't think this particular comment adds significant value.
 - Similarly the `EIP6065Mutable` bits of that comment should be removed.
 - Define RWA before its first use.
 - Foreclosure needs to be defined outside of a comment. What does that mean in terms of the token? Is it forcibly transferred to a different owner? Destroyed?
 - The debt stuff is under-specified. If the debt is a token, how is it "utilized specifically for off-chain debt"?
 - Link to your reference implementation file in the reference implementation section.
 - Remove `(*see pull request above*)` on line 180.
 - EIPs are not advertisements, so I'd like to see the reference implementation section de-klasma'd a bit. I'm fine with a "Klasma Labs offers a work in progress..." intro sentence, but I'd prefer everything after use fictitious company names.

5790, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-5528: Move to final', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-18T21:05:42.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-17T15:08:17.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-10-19T22:29:56.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-10-19T22:29:56.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "I've put up https://github.com/StartfundInc/EIPs-5528-review/pull/1 with some editorial changes.

Besides those changes, I think this EIP needs some more work before moving to the final state:

 - The difference between the *Payable Contract* and the *Escrow Contract* are not clearly explained enough. For example, it seems like they both implement `IERC5528` but behave differently.
 - There is some ambiguity about whether *Escrow Contract*s can implement policies beyond the list enumerated in this proposal. I'd add a line explicitly either allowing or prohibiting extra policies.
 - The instructions for implementing the *Payable Contract*'s functions are a bit confusing. Adding an example Solidity function call to demonstrate what you mean by calling the same function in the *Escrow Contract* with certain parameters would certainly help clear things up.
 - I think I missed replacing `_transfer` with `transfer` in a few places :sweat_smile: 
 - The Rationale section still has some grammar problems.
 - The section header describing policies is called `#### constructor`. I'm not sure if you mean to imply that these policies have to be set in the constructor, or if that was a mistake."}, {'prNumber': 5788, 'prTitle': "Update EIP-1155: Change title to 'Semi Fungible Token Standard'", 'reviewDate': '2022-10-18T21:15:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-16T15:58:40.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-14T19:06:40.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'This EIP is final, and this change does not correct an error. Unfortunately we cannot merge it.'}, {'prNumber': 5785, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-5750: Move to Review', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-18T15:38:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-15T17:54:02.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-10-31T11:56:57.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-10-31T11:56:57.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 5778, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-5615: Move to Review', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-24T18:23:49.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-11T12:57:58.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-25T21:22:25.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-11-25T21:22:25.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 5768, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-5496: Change status to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-18T15:32:29.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-08T13:59:40.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-16T01:41:47.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'Is `expires` a time or duration? Should clear that up in the docs for `setPrivilege`.

Change first line of `privilegeExpires` to `Return the expiry timestamp of a privilege`.

Replace all references to self (eg. `ERC5496` when not referring to `IERC5496`) with "this standard".

`transferPrivilege` is not defined in an interface.

`should better be less than 30 days` -> `should be less than 30 days`

The specifications for events seem a little vague. Should `PrivilegeAssigned` be emitted when `clonePrivilege` is called? If not, explain why in the rationale section.'}, {'prNumber': 5761, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-2135: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-21T19:07:53.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-06T15:24:02.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-02-06T00:18:08.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ' - Abstract is a bit light on details. Could maybe define what "consume" means, who is doing the consuming, etc.
 - `consumaed` is not a word.
 - Motivation section doesn't do a good job convincing me that we need an ERC for this (though it does touch on it.) As an example of the content I'd like to see, maybe mention what you'd expect wallets to do with this information? Maybe NFT marketplaces too (say displaying consumed tokens separately from unconsumed ones)?
 - Clarify whether `consume` burns the token. Right now it sounds like a compliant `consume` is allowed to not transfer ownership to the zero address, as long as it emits the event.
 - Please remove the external links to goerli in the Reference Implementation section. If you'd like to include a reference implementation, please put it in this EIP's `assets` directory.
 - Recommending an audit is good advice, but I think it applies to basically every EIP :rofl: You should imagine the Security Considerations section as a list of specific things _that auditors should pay attention to **for this EIP**_ and not as generic advice to smart contract developers.'}, {'prNumber': 5759, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-5679: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2022-10-18T15:48:56.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-10-06T15:05:10.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-10-27T12:59:26.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-10-27T12:59:26.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'Should EIP-165 support be optional? That would allow contracts with matching mint/burn functions to be compatible.

I'd expand on (6) a bit. I don't find "with respect to the `ERC721TokenReceiver`" clear enough. Maybe something like "`safeMint` MUST implement the same receiver restrictions as `safeTransferFrom` as defined in EIP-721".

`transfer` -> `transferred` on 68/69 and 73/74

You'll need to remove the external links to goerli.
