1. `Simple Summary` section has been removed.
2. A new `description` header field has been added that should contain a human readable one-line description of the EIP.
3. Remove external links.  Inline things as appropriate or just remove the reference entirely.
4. Remove the `Implementation` section.  This isn't a valid EIP section (also, the content in it isn't appropriate for an EIP).
5. Add missing Security Considerations section above Copyright section.
6. `Rationale for domainSeparator` needs an extra `#` leading it."}, {'prNumber': 4372, 'prTitle': 'Update offset and calculations', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-16T07:11:02.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-15T15:20:15.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-15T16:02:38.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-15T16:02:38.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4371, 'prTitle': "EIP-1: Removes preamble content that isn't used.", 'reviewDate': '2021-10-16T07:05:29.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-15T06:07:10.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-02T17:14:30.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4368, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-editors list.', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-15T06:08:23.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-14T16:11:49.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-15T06:08:39.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-15T06:08:39.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4367, 'prTitle': 'move eip-2464 from "stagnant" to "review"', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-15T06:20:35.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-14T15:42:20.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-02T16:57:12.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Test Cases section should be removed if there are no test cases.  It is an optional section.

`Security Considerations` section is missing but is required for all EIPs.

Recommend moving all but the last paragraph of the Abstract into the Motivation.  The abstract should just be a succinct human readable summary of the specification and should not go into the *why* at all.

Implementation isn't an EIP section so should be removed (also, external links should be removed).  `Reference Implementation` is a section, but should include an inline implementation (usually pseudocode) or a link to something in `../assets/eip-2464`.  In this case, I recommend just removing the section entirely."}, {'prNumber': 4366, 'prTitle': 'Move eip-2364 from "stagnant" to "review"', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-15T06:27:24.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-14T15:38:32.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-02T16:57:43.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Abstract should be cleaned up to just be a human readable summary of the specification, and not include rational/motivation related content.

First line of the specification should be removed or moved to the rationale.  The specification should be *only* the technical specification and not include reasoning/arguments.

The subheadings under the Rationale section should be `###` not `####` so automatic table of contents don't break or render incorrectly.

`Security Considerations` section is missing but required.

`Implementation` section should be removed as it is not an EIP section.  `Reference Implementation` is a valid section but should contain an inline implementation (usually pseudocode).

`Test Cases` section should include inline test cases, not a link to another repository.  Note that Test Cases section is optional, so you are welcome to leave it out or just include the first line (which references tests in EIP-2124)."}, {'prNumber': 4364, 'prTitle': 'Fix a typo and a grammatical error', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-14T11:04:52.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-14T03:45:20.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-14T11:06:25.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-14T11:06:25.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4362, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2718: Fix spelling of envelope in EIP-2718.', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-13T11:42:58.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-12T00:45:58.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-13T11:47:03.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-13T11:47:03.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4361, 'prTitle': 'Create EIP-4361: Sign-In with Ethereum', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-14T11:07:30.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-11T22:50:02.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-12-17T11:09:47.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-12-17T11:09:47.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4346, 'prTitle': 'Rewrite wildcard spec per feedback from ricmoo', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-13T12:07:53.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-05T22:54:30.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-28T19:31:08.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-28T19:31:08.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "I'll leave it to @lightclient to fully review this since I don't handle ERCs anymore, but wanted to at least get this out there to facilitate speeding up the review process.

The rest of the comments below are not required, but I recommend considering them at least.

----

Remove the external link to tests.  I encourage you to format test cases in a language agnostic way and include them as an asset (like you did with the implementation diff).  We should not be linking to external content though.

That being said, the one test case included already is fine and you could just remove the last line in the Test Cases section to fulfill this requirement.  As mentioned below, it would be nice if the test was a bit more clear about what it means to "fail".

----

Can you make the specification a bit more clear on how exactly the transaction should be rejected?  Consider wording like this:
> If a block contains a transaction whose signature recovers to an address where the `CODEHASH` of the address is not equal to `EMPTYCODEHASH`, then the block **MUST** be considered invalid by the client, similar to if the the block's timestamp was prior to its parent's timestamp.

The goal here is to clearly differentiate between "the transaction is entirely invalid and should not be allowed in the blockchain" and "the transcation is valid but reverts rather than executes".

----

In the reference implementation, consider being more clear about "transaction sender" and specifying that it is the address recovered from the transaction signature.

----

> An diff to implement ...

should be
> A diff to implement ...

----

> Every transaction send by the ...

should be
> Every transaction sent by the ...'}, {'prNumber': 4338, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-1523: Parameter handling', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-20T07:41:03.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-10-01T08:23:06.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-20T07:45:04.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-20T07:45:04.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 4337, 'prTitle': 'ERC: Account Abstraction via Entry Point Contract specification', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-04T04:43:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-09-29T08:57:30.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-08T03:28:21.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-08T03:28:21.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3773, 'prTitle': 'Add draft for ERC-3772', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-08T10:04:01.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-27T16:41:24.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-10-29T13:10:56.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-10-29T13:10:56.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3672, 'prTitle': 'ENS offchain resolution EIP', 'reviewDate': '2021-10-25T07:24:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-07-22T01:07:53.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-08T17:19:18.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}]

'2021-09-02T03:38:55.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Nothing major, mostly just some minor cleanup/correction things.

The one question I would advise considering before merging this that isn't just editorial is splitting this into 3 separate EIPs.  If you plan to do that (which I weakly recommend), then I suggest doing it before this gets merged as a draft (e.g., scrap this one and replace it with 3 others).  If you decide to keep this all as one EIP then that isn't a blocker.

I also would recommend extracting a good portion of the specification section out into the rationale.  Right now the specification section has a lot of "why" in it, but it should only have the "how".'}, {'prNumber': 3770, 'prTitle': '[EIP-3770] Chain-specific addresses', 'reviewDate': '2021-08-27T13:06:23.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-26T19:43:27.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-16T17:05:42.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-11-16T17:05:42.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3767, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-2315.md', 'reviewDate': '2021-08-28T11:11:56.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-25T04:53:03.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-08-28T18:41:12.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-08-28T18:41:12.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'All opcode references in the specification must be accompanied by their respective number with the format `REVERT (0xfe)`.  You can choose to only use this style for the first reference in the specification section, or for all of them, but it must be included in the first reference to each opcode.

----

For the new opcodes (BEGINSUB, JUMPSUB, RETURNSUB), I recommend just picking some unused ones for now.  We can always change them prior to final, but having a straw man for people to argue against has value in aiding discussion, prototype implementation, etc.

----

EIP dependencies should be included in the frontmatter with:
```md
requires: 3540
```

----

`[EVM Object Format (EOF)](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-3540)` needs to change to `[EIP-3540](./eip-3540.md)`.  I wouldn't be opposed to `[EIP-3540: EVM Object Format (EOF)](./eip-3540.md)` either if you like having the title present (I do think the title adds value).  The key is that the link should be relative, and the EIP number should be included in the link title in its proper format (`EIP-####`).

----

External link to closed EVMOne pull request should be removed.  If this EIP depends on a standardized change, then that should be an EIP itself.  If the EVMOne change is just an example of a necessary change that clients will need to make, then I recommend briefly describing the necessary change here.

----

Reference to 615 in the Rationale and 3337 in the Backward compatibility should both be removed, or those EIPs should be moved to Review prior to this EIP moving to review.  I recommend just removing the links though, as neither add meaningful value in a world where they don't make it to final (which is the world we should be authoring in if they remain in stages lower than this EIP).

----

The Implementation section is no longer a standard EIP section.  It was replaced with the optional Reference Implementation section which should contain either an inline implementation or pseudocode implementation, or a link to `../assets/3767/*` which contains a reference implementation.  If you want to track implementation progress later in the process, https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs is the appropriate place to do so.

----

The Costs and Codes section should be a subsection of the Specification.  It is impossible to implement this EIP in a consensus compatible way without gas costs, so it should go there.  Also, EIPs should not "suggest", they should assert.  My recommendation is to just put the gas costs in the ## Specification section directly along with each opcode's definition and then in the ## Rationale section you can describe your reasoning and methodology for each.

----

TODO, Appendix, and References sections are not standard EIP sections and should be removed.  EIPs are not the appropriate place to discuss future works or pass around acknowledgements.  They should be purely technical standards.  I strongly encourage all EIP authors to draft a separate document somewhere like hackmd or similar that tracks things that aren't explicitly related to the standard.  This includes collections of links, references, various external implementations, etc.'}, {'prNumber': 3756, 'prTitle': 'Create eip to cap gas limit', 'reviewDate': '2021-08-21T16:45:40.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-21T15:00:03.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-08-23T07:58:49.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-08-23T07:58:49.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3754, 'prTitle': '[EIP-3754] A vanilla non-fungible token standard', 'reviewDate': '2021-08-22T03:15:57.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-21T14:38:43.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-09-25T16:52:00.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-09-25T16:51:59.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3750, 'prTitle': 'Set 2681 to Final and 3338 to Withdrawn', 'reviewDate': '2021-08-20T14:56:40.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-20T14:47:22.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-08-20T15:37:58.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-08-20T15:37:58.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3742, 'prTitle': '[EIP-3742] - Should be about one sentence.

The image at the top of the document should be removed.  EIPs should follow the template in terms of layout and avoid adding extraneous things that may break a future renderer.

There are a large number of sections that aren't part of the template.  See https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ethereum/EIPs/master/eip-template.md for the set of standard sections.  If you want to include additional information, it should be in one of those sections.

There is no `Implementation` section, only `Reference Implementation` and it should contain code, not a link to external code.  This is an optional section though, so can be removed entirely if inlining a reference implementation doesn't make sense.

`Backward Compatibility` section should describe potential issues with prior existing code/specs in production, not describe how this standard might be forward compatible.  A single sentence indicating no known backward compatibility issues is acceptable if there aren't any.

All of the external links should be removed from this document.  EIPs are technical standards, not an appropriate place to collect links and materials.

Lastly, the discovery protocol is just one way to find peers, but systems that cannot use UDP or that rely on other mechanism (e.g. DNS discovery ([EIP-1459](./eip-1459.md))) still need a way to filter connections.

EIP-1459 is still in review, not final, which means it is blocking this from being merged.  Since it is just used as an example, can we just remove it?

> Additionally, `forkid` validation via the discovery protocol requires ENR implementation ([EIP-778](./eip-778.md)) and ENR extension support ([EIP-868](./eip-868.md)), which is not mandated by the Ethereum network currently. ----

Personal note (not a blocker for EIP), which I can add to the discussions-to once it is available:

On a separate note, I disagree with this change.  It doesn't add value to the protocol and it breaks backward compatibility.  Any wallet/signing tool that wants this can easily add it and we don't benefit from adding it to the core protocol in ways that we cannot achieve by just convincing wallets/signers to add it.

In general, anything that can be solved at a higher layer than the core protocol I believe should be solved at a higher layer than the core protocol, and the core protocol should be as permissive as possible when given a choice between permissive and restrictive."}, {'prNumber': 3781, 'prTitle': 'Create eip-3779.md', 'reviewDate': '2021-09-02T03:31:46.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-30T05:57:12.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-09-02T03:38:55.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-09-02T03:38:55.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3770, 'prTitle': '[EIP-3770] Chain-specific addresses', 'reviewDate': '2021-09-02T07:31:44.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-26T19:43:27.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-16T17:05:42.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-11-16T17:05:42.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3768, 'prTitle': 'Fix "nonpayble" typo', 'reviewDate': '2021-09-07T04:27:38.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-08-26T05:09:09.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-09-07T04:29:46.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-09-07T04:29:46.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}]

'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 2825, 'prTitle': '2309 last call', 'reviewDate': '2020-07-25T02:52:52.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-07-25T02:12:04.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-07-26T00:25:33.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-07-26T00:25:33.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Required change: You **MUST** have a `review-period-end` line in the header when moving an EIP to last call.  This should be at least 2 weeks from today, more is acceptable as well.

----

I recommend having a separate event for mint, burn, and transfer.  The ecosystem stumbled on the "transfer to 0" pattern on accident because the original ERC20 standard was way under-specified and people had to improvise.  When creating any new standard, I do not recommend following in those footsteps unless it is absolutely necessary.

If you choose to keep a single transfer event for mint, burn, and transfer then consider including the reasoning why in the rationale.

----

> This can lead to bugs and unnecessary complex logic for platforms using these events to track token ownership.

This line from the specification should be moved to the Rationale.  The specification should, ideally, be mostly free from discussion and focus explicitly on the specification.

----

Consider removing the comments and `#pragma solidity` from the Solidity code block.  The only thing that is actually part of the interface is the event itself. Consider also dropping the `interface` wrapper.

----

The implementation section isn't required for non-core EIPs I don't believe.  The current line in the Implementation section just links out to what appears to be a general purpose website not having anything to do with this EIP, so that should be removed even if you retain the implementation section.  If you want to retain the implementation section, I recommend including an implementation inline in the EIP rather than linking out to it.  If you go this route, keep things as minimal as possible.'}, {'prNumber': 2821, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-2569.md', 'reviewDate': '2020-07-22T05:42:19.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-07-22T04:34:38.000Z', 27 | While ERC-20 tokens have become ubiquitous in the Ethereum ecosystem, their status remains that of second class tokens from the perspective of the protocol. The ability for users to interact with Ethereum without holding any ETH has been a [long outstanding goal](./eip-101.md) and the [subject](./eip-1077.md) [of](./eip-777.md) [many](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/1776) [EIPs](./eip-1271.md).
   |

29 | So far, many of these proposals have seen very little adoption, and the ones that have been adopted (such as [ERC-777](./eip-777.md)), introduce a lot of additional functionality, causing [unexpected behavior in mainstream contracts](https://medium.com/consensys-diligence/uniswap-audit-b90335ac007).
   |

1. For `IERC721NOA`, **specify what happens when someone calls `ownerOf` on a `tokenId` that is owned by an NOA.** Should it throw? Return the zero address? This is ambiguous right now.

Here are some suggestions for other changes that I feel the standard is lacking:

2. Add methods to `IERC721NOA` and `IERC20NOA` that allow users to transfer tokens *to* NOAs, and get the balance of NOAs.
3. Add an NOA extension for EIP-1155. Since I cannot make changes on unmodified lines (thanks GitHub!), here are my suggestions:

Title: I would prefer if you renamed this EIP to something like "Modular Contract Accounts"
Line 15: Replace `ERC-5005 (Zodiac Avatar Accounts)` with `This EIP`
Line 15: This EIP is not a philosophy, unless you consider the question "how does one make a good contract account" one of the fundamental questions of the universe. In that case, go ahead :)
Line 18: This might be a good time to mention separation of concerns.
Line 20: Replace `Zodiac standard` with `this EIP`
Line 30: Replace `The Zodiac standard` with `This EIP`
Line 30: Replace `-` with `: `
Line 211: I would prefer if you expanded this line into multiple lines.
Line 216: I suggest this wording change: `The interface defined in this standard is designed to be mostly compatible with most popular programmable accounts in use right now, to minimize the need for changes to existing tooling.`
Line 222: Replace the `.` with a `:`
Line 223-224: Replace `unilateral` with `absolute`
Line 225: Remove `Be warned`. This entire section is supposed to be a big warning. Your users have already been warned.

'reviewComment': "Reference implementation should only contain the minimum code possible to exemplify an implementation of this standard.  It doesn't have to be complete or even compile out of the box and it shouldn't include an entire build system, tooling, nor any extraneous features.  I recommend deleting everything in `assets/eip-5334` except the ERC5334.sol file.

----

For test cases, this should be something that is portable to any environment a future reader may be using and not tightly coupled with a particular language/test tooling.  Usually this means a JSON file or something that has `function, inputs, expected_outputs, expected_exceptions` or something.  You may want additional columns for expected post-conditions as well.

The readme also shouldn't be included, nor should the .gitignore."}, {'prNumber': 5320, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP-5320: Harberger Taxes NFT', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-24T08:43:01.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-24T07:17:52.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-12-25T00:18:53.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Make sure you address all of the feedback from the bot (see inline comments in files tab in GitHub), and address any CI failures that appear to be problems with the EIP.'}, {'prNumber': 5319, 'prTitle': 'Re-Add Comment Cleaner', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-24T04:51:13.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-23T22:31:46.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-07-25T00:52:40.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 5312, 'prTitle': 'Improvify GitHub Action', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-23T04:24:44.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-22T19:01:53.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-07-23T12:07:46.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-07-23T12:07:46.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 5311, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-173: Add EIP-165 dependency', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-23T04:02:55.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-22T18:51:03.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-26T00:17:38.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "With approval by one of the authors and buy-in from the other editors, I think I would be OK with making all suggested eipw changes *except* for the `discussions-to` link change.

Regarding the currently proposed changes, `type` header field should come immediately before `category` header field so at least we aren't making the situation worse."}, {'prNumber': 5300, 'prTitle': 'Create EIP-5298: ENS Trust to hold NFTs under ENS name', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-21T07:43:57.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-20T23:27:43.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-15T15:09:54.000Z', 'merged_at': '2022-11-15T15:09:54.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 5299, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP-5299: Storage scaling pattern', 'reviewDate': '2022-07-21T05:35:36.000Z', 'created_at': '2022-07-20T11:22:26.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-11-11T00:23:34.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "This EIP feels like a Good Idea, rather than a standard.  EIPs generally should be things that need to be standardized, and it isn't really an appropriate place to author/store design patterns or other Good Ideas.

For example, a standard should essentially never have private/internal methods, it should only describe the public surface area and the invariants that can be expected to be maintained by the caller of those methods.  This proposal is almost entirely made up of internal/private members suggesting that it is a Good Idea/Design Pattern, not a standard.

Another way to look at this is to ask whether there is a many-to-many relationship between callers and callees or not.  For Twitter API, there is one server serving the data and many users which means a standard is not necessary as Twitter can just publish API docs.  For web browsers on the other hand, there are many web browsers and many web pages and we want all browsers to be able to render all pages, so we need standards."}, {'prNumber': 5292, 'prTitle': 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "Most of the feedback can wait until a later stage of the process, though I encourage you to address it all.  The Formatting and incorrect sections stuff should be addressed before draft though.

On a non-editorial note, I don't believe this actually solves the problem you want it to solve because miners can still order transactions however they want and there already exist out-of-band miner payment systems so you aren't even going to protect users if this were released today.

The best solution to front-running like this is a commit-reveal scheme where the fraud provider would commit a hash of the fraud proof and then one or more blocks later reveal the preimage for the fraud proof.  This adds a bit of complexity, but since fraud proofs are likely being executed as bots that can largely be ignored and the increased gas costs should be relatively low compared to the actual fraud proof execution."}, {'prNumber': 3331, 'prTitle': '3085: Add scalingFactor field to nativeCurrency', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-06T06:12:54.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-05T17:25:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-05-12T07:16:24.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3330, 'prTitle': 'EIP-3198 Draft -> Review', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-06T06:08:06.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-05T15:32:09.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-09T11:37:21.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-09T11:37:21.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Needs an Abstract.  Consider renaming Simple Summary to Abstract and then writing a new Simple Summary like "Adds an opcode that gives the EVM access to the block's base fee.".

----

Needs Rationale to be filled out.  I recommend at least discussing why you decided on the chosen gas cost.

----

Needs Security Considerations.  If there are no known security considerations mention that.

----

Recommend rewording Backward Compatibility to "There are no known backward compatibility issues with this opcode." to match phrasing in other EIPs.'}, {'prNumber': 3325, 'prTitle': '3085: Move to Review', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-05T08:01:30.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-04T21:24:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-06T06:21:33.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-06T06:21:33.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Only blocking issue is the reference to a draft EIP.  The rest is feedback that can be applied after merging to Review (or before if you desire).

----

Remove the last line of the abstract, as it is implicit in how all EIPs are structured.
> Important cautions for implementers of this method are included in the Security Considerations section.

----

> A request for a chain that was already added SHOULD be considered successful.

should be
> A request to add a chain that was already added SHOULD be considered successful.

Also, I think this should actually say:
> A request to add a chain that was already added **MUST** be considered successful if the chains match (defining "match" is up to the provider), and **MUST** return an error otherwise.

Stronger wording in specifications is almost always preferred over weaker wording, otherwise it turns into a "best practices" document and not a standard.  Also, I think that the matching component should be a hard requirement with a well defined error.

----

> The wallet SHOULD NOT allow the same chainId to be added multiple times.

Why is this not **MUST NOT**?  Feels like it is asking for problems to allow it.  Side note: I feel like `hasEthereumChain` should come first, as without that it means this specification cannot reasonably put a MUST here even though the spec should put a MUST here and could put a MUST here if `hasEthereumChain` was an existing standard.

----

Recommend including the code and message for standardized errors.  Having consistent error messaging makes building dapps *way* easier than if you have to try to guess what went wrong or give the user a generic error message (that likely isn't helpful in troubleshooting).

----

> Verify that the specified chain ID matches the return value of eth_chainId from the endpoint, as described in [this specification](...).

should be
> Verify that the specified chain ID matches the return value of eth_chainId from the endpoint, as described [above](...).

This makes it more clear that you aren't linking out to an external specification.

----

Remove reference to EIP-1102 as it is still just a draft.  Alternatively, push EIP-1102 through to Review first, then move this to review.'}, {'prNumber': 3322, 'prTitle': 'EIP 3322: Efficient Gas Storage', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-05T07:15:16.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-04T18:42:45.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-05T07:20:40.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-05T07:20:40.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3310, 'prTitle': 'Change EIP-2537 status from "Draft" to "Review"', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-03T08:47:41.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-02T20:31:53.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-03T10:27:50.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "`Important notes` isn't an EIP section.  Its contents should be moved to `Specifictaion`, `Security Considerations`, or `Rationale` section.  Consider creating a sub-section in one of those.

----

Don't skip nesting levels (`##` to `####` without going through `###` first) as this breaks table of contents and potentially proper formatting in some renderers.

----

Consider adding gas cost per precompile to the abstract table (at least the high level bits, doesn't have to be exhaustive and a gas cost range is fine for the abstract).

----

Test cases need to be moved to the EIPs repository.  `../assets/eip-2537/*` is fine if there are too many to reasonably inline.

----

The implementation section should either be removed or contain a reference implementation inline, or a link to a reference implementation in `../assets/eip-2537/*`.  I recommend just removing it as it is an optional section and I'm guessing a reference implementation would not be trivial to pack up into a few files in the assets directory.  If you do retain this section, rename it to `Reference Implementation` to align with https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ethereum/EIPs/master/eip-template.md.

----

Consider breaking this EIP up into one EIP per precompile.  Generally, smaller EIPs are much easier to get included.  While I can appreciate that describing BLS-381 in one EIP is easier, you could describe BLS in one place and then have an EIP (that depends on that generalized BLS description) for each precompile so you don't have to repeat yourself."}, {'prNumber': 3309, 'prTitle': 'Change EIP-2315 status from "Draft" to "Review"', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-03T07:52:40.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-02T20:25:33.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-05-09T08:11:19.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'The first reference to each new opcode in the Specification section must be in the form `OPCODE (0xNN)`.  e.g., `BEGINSUB (0x5c)`

----

Implementations section should be removed (or reworked).  An inline reference implementation would be acceptable, or something in `../assets/eip-2315/*`.  External links to implementations tend to result in 404s over time and implementations that people care about in 5 years are unlikely to be the same implementations that people care about today.

----

The costs and opcodes need to be moved to the `Specification` section.  They also should not "suggest", but instead they should assert.

----

`Appendix: Comparative costs.` isn't a valid EIP section.  Recommend just removing it as it doesn't add value to future implementers and instead is just an argument for why to implement this (which is appropriate for the Motivation section).'}, {'prNumber': 3308, 'prTitle': 'mark 2612 for last call', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-03T10:16:45.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-02T16:37:11.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-05-06T18:21:37.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'This EIP depends on EIP-712 but EIP-712 is still in draft.  Either convince the authors to move that EIP forward, or create your own EIP that this can depend on.  This likely will block forward movement/progress of this EIP so I recommend addressing this ASAP.

----

Simple Summary should be much shorter.  Think email subject line, GitHub PR title, forum thread title, etc.  Most of the content currently in the simple summary would be better suited in the motivation section.

----

The abstract should be a summary of the Specification section in a human readable form.  It doesn't need to cover all of the edge cases or minutia, but it should give the reader a high level overview of the specification.  All of the current content in the Abstract should be moved to the Motivation section.

----

Avoid linking to non-final EIPs anywhere in the EIP.

When you link EIPs, it should also be to `./eip-###.md` (never to GitHub).

----

In the motivation section, try to avoid spending too much time talking about history.  Instead, talk about use cases that are fulfilled by this EIP (consider just deleting the whole first three paragraphs of the Motivation section).

Keep in mind, EIPs are technical documents and not argumentative essays, repositories of history, etc.  The purpose of the motivation section is to simply give readers a high level overview of use cases for the EIP and why someone would want to use it, not to convince a naysayer of its value.

----

EIPs should always be in the format `EIP-###` when referenced.  `ERC20` is incorrect.

----

The Rationale should indicate why certain design choices were made over other options.  The current contents of the Rationale would be more appropriate in the Motivation section (which is for describing use cases for the EIP in general).  An example design decision might be why a particular constant was chosen over another, why a particular name was chosen, other patterns, etc.

----

Backward compatibility section should be higher level.  Rather than pointing at specific instances of alternate implementations, just mention that there are incompatible implementations in the wild and potentially how incompatibility with them could be addressed by an application author.  Definitely don't link to external sources.

----

Either inline the test cases, add them to `../assets/eip-2612/*` or remove the section (it is optional).

----

Remove the Implementation section or add a reference implementation inline or add a reference implementation to `../assets/eip-2612/*`.

----

Don't externally link to documents tin the Security Considerations section.  I wouldn't even bother mentioning the ERC-20 approval issue, as it is a "problem" with ERC-20 and not with this specification.

----

The comment about domain separator feels like it should be in the Security Considerations section of EIP-712, not this EIP.

----

Remove everything after the license, that should be the last section.  I'm not sure what that is supposed to be referencing, but inlining would be preferred.'}, {'prNumber': 3305, 'prTitle': 'Update EIP-2070 pointing to eth1.0-specs', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-01T18:52:40.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-03-01T18:44:35.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-02T05:29:53.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-02T05:29:53.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3302, 'prTitle': 'EIP-2228: Promote to Review', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-02T13:34:41.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-28T16:16:35.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-11T04:46:23.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-11T04:46:22.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Recommend removing Vitalik's name from the motivation.  I think it is better to just refer to it being called XXX in EIP-YYY rather than appealing to authority and saying who the speaker was in each case.

----

EIP links must be in the form `[EIP-XXX](./eip-XXX.md)`

----

Remove the external link to Geth.  We can instead just say that some client documentation calls it `mainnet`.

----

Consider just mentioning in the motivation that it is called X, Y, and Z in various EIPs and around the internet.  Presumably, once we finalize this EIP someone will go through and clean up the EIPs with the incorrect name at which point all of the links to "evidence" will no longer make sense.  If the motivation of this EIP just says "there are places where it is called these other things" then we don't have to worry about their mutability.

----

Remove `## References` section, it isn't a standard EIP section.

----

Remove `## Implementation` section, it isn't a required section and since it contains no reference implementation it can be removed.'}, {'prNumber': 3300, 'prTitle': 'EIP-3300: Phase Out Refunds', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-01T19:29:07.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-27T00:31:40.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-02T15:10:05.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-02T15:10:05.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3296, 'prTitle': 'Fixes some misspelled words, grammar and comprehension', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-02T13:02:40.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-26T05:00:39.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-02T13:06:22.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-02T13:06:22.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3269, 'prTitle': 'Move 2678 to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-09T11:42:59.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-02-16T11:57:15.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-09T11:51:29.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-09T11:51:29.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3220, 'prTitle': 'EIP-crosschain-id proposal', 'reviewDate': '2021-03-02T08:39:56.000Z', 'created_at': '2021-01-25T20:56:25.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-03-03T13:10:23.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-03-03T13:10:23.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "While none of the changes proposed here are *required* for a merge to draft, many of them will block a merge to Review status. '2020-10-28T05:23:54.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-10-28T05:23:54.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Abstract should describe the specification in a human readable way in relatively few words:
> Standard functions a token contract and contracts working with tokens can implement to make a token Payable.
> 
> `transferAndCall` and `transferFromAndCall` will call an `onTransferReceived` on a `ERC1363Receiver` contract.
> `approveAndCall` will call an `onApprovalReceived` on a `ERC1363Spender` contract.

----

Motivation should describe *why* this standard is valuable and how it can be used.  Most of what you have in there at the moment is more appropriate for Abstract.  Also, other EIPs should be linked to (see below).
> This proposal is inspired by the [ERC-721](./eip-721.md) `onERC721Received` and `ERC721TokenReceiver` behaviors.
> 
> There are many proposed uses of Ethereum smart contracts that can accept ERC-20 payments (i.e. to create a token payable crowdsale, selling services for tokens, paying invoices, making subscriptions, use them for a specific utility and many other purposes). 
> 
> This proposal wants to make token payments easier and working without the use of any other listener. It also allows to make a callback after a transfer in a single transaction.

----

In Specification section change
> Every Payable Token compliant contract **MUST** implement the ERC-1363 interface as well as the ERC-20 and ERC-165 interfaces.

to
> Implementing contracts **MUST** implement the [ERC-1363](./eip-1363.md) interface as well as the [ERC-20](./eip-20.md) and [ERC-165](eip-165.md) interfaces.

----

The Rationale section should describe why you made specific choices you did in the EIP.  For example, why did you choose a constant value of X, or why did you choose function name Y.  The content you have in there currently is more appropriate for the Motivation section and should be removed from the Rationale section.

----

In the backward compatibility section, be sure to link to external EIPs you reference.

----

Whenever possible, we prefer to avoid linking to external resources. 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 7265, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: Circuit Breaker', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-18T16:47:25.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-07-03T06:55:44.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-10-25T22:52:43.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 7229, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: Minimal Upgradable Proxy Contract', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-25T17:19:33.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-06-24T15:37:09.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-10-25T17:19:43.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': "You _could_ slim down your example code a bit. We try to keep reference implementations minimal.

---

The big overall comment here is that you aren't proposing a _standard_, you're proposing a specific implementation. We don't generally allow specific implementations to be published as EIPs.

EIPs shine when multiple different parties have to coordinate to implement a system. For example, ERC-20 is a great example of what an EIP should be because every wallet wants to work with every ERC-20 token, and every ERC-20 token wants to work with every wallet.

This EIP doesn't really coordinate anything. If someone wants to use your bytecode, they can just use it without having to coordinate with anyone else.

This isn't me saying your bytecode doesn't have value. It absolutely does, and you should promote it as much as possible. Just not in the EIPs repository.

---

I'm going to close this PR, but feel free to re-open it if you would like to rewrite it as a standard instead of an implementation."}, {'prNumber': 7169, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: Tranche Sequence', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-24T23:12:24.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-06-12T14:59:14.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-10-25T22:18:50.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'A bit of overall feedback on this proposal: libraries do not need to be EIPs. Just write the library. You only need an EIP if you expect different independent parties to have to coordinate on a system. For example, ERC-20 is a good proposal because wallets need to interact with any number of different tokens, and every ERC-20 token wants to work with every wallet.

If you wish to standardize **the interface** for a library, and expect there to be multiple implementations, then an EIP is a good idea.'}, {'prNumber': 7158, 'prTitle': 'Add EIP: NFT Dynamic Ownership', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-24T21:37:09.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-06-09T01:59:26.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-10-25T22:17:33.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', '2023-11-14T15:26:11.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-11-14T15:26:10.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'Line 64 says:

> `lock` function MUST revert if token is **not** already locked.

Emphasis mine. This seems backwards?

---

A bit later you write:

> ERC-721 `_tansfer` function [...]

ERC-721 doesn't have a `_tansfer` function (nor `_transfer`), so these requirements don't make sense. You may be thinking of the OpenZeppelin implementation, which does have `_transfer`.

You can't depend on a specific implementation of ERC-721 in a standard, so you should reword this to be more general. Something like:

> ERC-721 functions that transfer ownership of a token MUST revert [...]

---

Line 66's use of "setup" is a bit ambiguous. I'd recommend being more explicit.'}, {'prNumber': 44, 'prTitle': 'Update ERC-3643: Move to Last Call', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-31T15:44:30.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-10-27T07:56:26.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-11-14T15:52:39.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-11-14T15:52:39.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 33, 'prTitle': 'Add ERC: Contract Discovery and eTLD+1 Association', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-30T17:34:33.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-10-26T21:10:16.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-12-18T16:24:11.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-12-18T16:24:11.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 20, 'prTitle': 'add erc-7509', 'reviewDate': '2023-10-30T20:57:38.000Z', 'created_at': '2023-10-26T07:05:19.000Z', 'closed_at': '2023-11-21T03:42:41.000Z', 'merged_at': '2023-11-21T03:42:40.000Z', 'repo': 'ERCs', 'reviewer': 'SamWilsn', 'reviewComment': 'I think this is good to go for draft. [{'prNumber': 3181, 'prTitle': 'erc-3156 ready for review', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-31T06:56:33.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-30T21:29:14.000Z', 'closed_at': '2021-01-15T03:50:46.000Z', 'merged_at': '2021-01-15T03:50:46.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': '> If a fee is charged, the contract implementing flashLoan MAY use it in any desired way (e.g. the fee can be burned or transferred to any other party).

This is unnecessary in the spec.  A spec shouldn't try to define all of the things that it doesn't specify, it should focus exclusively on the things it does specify.  This makes the specification much smaller and thus easier for a human to work with and implement.

> If the flashLoan used tokens generated by a mint, they SHOULD be the target of a burn before the end of the transaction.

This feels out of scope.  This specification is defining an interface, and shouldn't try to dictate what people do inside implementations of that interface.

> The flashLoan function MUST verify that the tokens lended were returned, and MUST NOT take them from the receiver.

Rephrase this to specify what the expected behavior is if the lender has not received the lent tokens + fees.  Also note that currently this doesn't specify the fee needs to be paid here.

> The lender contract MAY mint the tokens lended, instead of executing a transfer of tokens it holds.

As above, this is out of scope of the specification and not actually a specification but rather a suggestion.  Suggestions aren't appropriate for technical specifications and they add unnecessary length that doesn't add value to interoperability.

> A receiver of flash mints MUST implement an onFlashLoan callback:

I think you mean `flash loans` here, not `flash mints`.

> For the transaction to not revert, receiver MUST send amount + fee of token to the caller.

This should be more technically specific.  Something like "amount + fee of token **MUST** be transferred to the `msg.sender` of the `onFlashLoan` function at some point prior to returning from `onFlashLoan`.

> flashSupply returns zero on unsupported contracts to allow for borrowers to discover the lending services offered by an ERC-3156 compliant lender.

This cannot be guaranteed.  You should use something like ERC-165 or ERC-1820 if you want such guarantees.

----

Are there any security issues with reentrancy that implementers need to worry about?  I thought there were some problems with naive implementations of flash loans where someone could drain the lender via reentrancy.  If so, those should be discussed in the Security Considerations section.

----

Remove the test cases section if you don't plan on inlining the tests.  External links from EIPs should be avoided as much as possible, and this section isn't required.

----

Remove the first 3 paragraphs in `## Implementation` section.  EIPs are not the appropriate venue to collect/maintain external links to things.  The inline implementation is fine, and if people want to learn more they can search the internet or check the `discussions-to` link.'}, {'prNumber': 3171, 'prTitle': 'Add CREATE3 opcode - no init_code hash', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-23T04:47:12.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-22T18:58:34.000Z', 'closed_at': '2022-01-09T08:13:50.000Z', 'merged_at': None, 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3170, 'prTitle': 'Request peer review for ERC-681', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-24T05:37:05.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-22T11:00:55.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-31T08:33:55.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-12-31T08:33:55.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': "I believe `ether` should be used rather than `Ethers`.  I don't *think* pluralizing it is appropriate, nor do  *believe* it is correct for it to be capitalized as a proper noun.  I am curious to hear arguments against this though.

----

`## Backwards Compatibility` and `## Security Considerations` sections are required (after `## Rationale` section).

----

`Compatibility and Versioning` section is not a standard section and should be removed (consider moving its current contents over to the `Rationale` section describing the `erc831_part`).

----

EIP-831 is not currently final, which means this EIP cannot go to final.  You will either need to remove the dependency, or get that EIP get it final, or fork that EIP and get your forked EIP to final and then depend on that.

----

The first reference (at least) to an EIP within this document must be of the form `[EIP-123](./eip-123.md)`.  Also, all EIPs must be referred to as `EIP-XXX` or `ERC-XXX` not `EIP #XXX`.

----

Why does `ethereum_address` start with `0x`.  We already know the encoding from context (reading a URI) so it is just wasted characters that serve no purpose.

----

The UNIT part of this specification is problematic at best.  Consider just removing it.

The spec says that if there is a symbol field on the contract and a decimals field then the value should be multiplied by 10^decimals.  This means that if someone creates a URL to send `10e18 DAI`, a spec compliant implementation will attempt to send `10e36 DAI`, which is almost certainly not the intent.

The spec doesn't say what to do if there is no UNIT provided but contract access is available.  Should it still multiply the provided value by decimals?

It seems that the spec should fail if a non-empty `UNIT` is provided and blockchain access is not available, rather than succeed as the signer has no way of validating that the units provided are correct.  I could create a transfer URL for `1e18 microETH` and the signer would blindly render this, and then proceed to send 1e18 ETH instead.  Given non-verifiable information, tools should prefer to protect the user rather than put them in danger.

Why is this specification dictating what tooling MUST/MUST NOT do with the data (like requiring they fail in certain situations)?  This seems like something that should be left up to the tooling to decide what is most appropriate for their users.  For example, I may have an offline signer that has no blockchain access but **DOES** have a pre-seeded list of well known token details.

----

In general, **SHOULD** and **MAY** statements aren't great for specs since they don't add any value in standardization and are really just style guidelines that should be left for other resources like blog posts, tutorials, etc.

----

What happens if the user supplies a non-integer value like `1.2345e2`?

----

Security Considerations section should go into great detail about all of the potential attack vectors and the trust model required to use these URL."}, {'prNumber': 3160, 'prTitle': 'Bump 2678 to Review status', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-12T05:13:26.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-11T11:02:22.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-19T13:24:56.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-12-19T13:24:56.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': 'Recommend adding something to the rationale indicating why these are minified.  There doesn't seem to be any obvious benefit to doing so as JSON doesn't minify particularly well (you only can clear out newlines and tabs, both of which gzip will compress quite well).

The "Guiding Principles" subsection of the specification should be in the `Motivation` section.  The specification should be *purely* a technical specification and not discuss any of the "why".

The first paragraph of the specification should be moved to motivation or removed (I think it is redundant).

The second paragraph of the specification should be removed.  It isn't part of the specification and is redundant with EIP process documentation and likely to become out of date if/when the EIP repository or hosted site moves.

Can this specification just be a JSON schema with comments?  Having it written as an english language specification seems like it just makes it much longer and more confusing than necessary.

The document constraints should all have an entry in the rationale section as they seem unnecessarily restrictive to the naive reader, thus are deserving of explanation as to why they exist.  Separately, I recommend removing most of the constraints and accepting any valid JSON file, which is already a well specified format.

Recommend adding a rationale entry for the constraints on the package name field.  This is 2020, every reasonable system supports full UTF-8 strings for pretty much everything so constraining to a subset of UTF-8 is deserving of an explanation.

Don't link externally to `package.spec.json`.  Instead, put a copy in `../assets/eip-2678/package.spec.json` and link to it as a relative path link.

Literal values are defined as a `byte string`, but that isn't defined in this specification.  I believe the concept of a byte string is a python thing, so not all developers will be familiar with it and thus I think it is worth defining explicitly.

The source checksum should be mentioned in the Rationale section.  JSON is essentially *always* sent over a transport that has built-in error checking/checksumming so having another one seems redundant.  On top of that, only having a checksum on the source but not the rest of the file is surprising.  From a security standpoint, a checksum that is distributed with the source is pointless as if one is compromised then so is the other.

This specification seems to have a lot of overlap with the Solidity compiler input JSON.  Has there been any attempt to work with them to have a single consolidated manifest file rather than two competing specifications?

Recommend adding a rationale entry for why BIP122 was chosen.  Since this specification is ETH specific (`EthPM`), it seems unnecessary at first glance to use BIP122 which is not generally used within this ecosystem.

The current contents of the Rationale should be moved to the Motivation section.  The Rationale is for giving reasoning why specific design choices were made, while the motivation section is for explaining why this specification may be useful to someone.  Use cases are a great piece of content for the motivation section.

Try to avoid linking externally, such as to EthPM repository.  Instead, it is recommended to inline or use the assets directory.  IF this specification is tightly coupled with EthPM, consider just including it in the EthPM documentation rather than using the EIPs repository for it.

Remove the Implementations section.  It is no longer part of the EIP template.

`Further Work` isn't part of the EIP template and isn't appropriate for a technical specification.  Consider putting such content in a blog, documentation site, project tracker, etc. rather than in the technical spec.

Acknowledgements shouldn't be included in EIPs.  EIPs are CC0 licensed which means no attribution is necessary.  Consider including shoutouts, acknowledgements, kudos, attributions, etc. in a Tweet or launch post rather than the technical document.

Remove this line from the Security Considerations and instead re-write (copy/paste if necessary) any security considerations for this EIP rather than making people go hunt them down elsewhere:
> The same security considerations from v2 are still relevant for EthPM v3.'}, {'prNumber': 3155, 'prTitle': '3155: Create EVM Trace Specification', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-09T01:33:20.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-07T15:38:33.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-09T02:39:53.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-12-09T02:39:53.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3153, 'prTitle': 'Update eip-1 implementation definition', 'reviewDate': '2020-12-05T08:19:03.000Z', 'created_at': '2020-12-05T07:32:02.000Z', 'closed_at': '2020-12-05T08:19:10.000Z', 'merged_at': '2020-12-05T08:19:10.000Z', 'repo': 'EIPs', 'reviewer': 'MicahZoltu', 'reviewComment': ''}, {'prNumber': 3144, 'prTitle': 'Adds chainId and yParity;
